text:
Police: Man attacks family member

JONESBORO \- A man suspected of assaulting a female family member Wednesday
was being held in jail on a $150,000 bond.

The victim reported Wednesday that Nathaniel Rhodes, 37, of Jonesboro, broke
into her house and attacked her while she was sleeping in the 1000 block of
Ferrell Street, reports state. According to the Jonesboro Police Department
incident report, Rhodes picked the lock on the back door to enter the home.

"She reported that Rhodes repeatedly punched and choked her during the
assault.  Rhodes took his hand and covered her mouth and nose," the probable
cause affidavit read. "When Rhodes was attacking the victim, he made threats
that he was going to kill her."

District Court Judge Tommy Fowler found probable cause Friday to charge Rhodes
with residential burglary, aggravated assault on a family or household member
and first-degree terroristic threatening.

As a pre-trial condition, Fowler said Rhodes is required to wear an ankle
monitor if he is released from jail. A no-contact order between him and the
victim was also imposed.

\-----

The judge also found probable cause for charges and set bond for the
following:

Michael Bridgeman, 30, of Jonesboro, possession of meth less than 2 grams,
possession of drug paraphernalia; bond set at $3,500, cash or surety.

Daniel Cohn, 29, of Jonesboro, possession of drug paraphernalia; bond set at
$1,500, cash or surety.

Danna Holt, 36, of Leachville, possession of meth less than 2 grams,
possession of marijuana less than 4 ounces; bond set at $1,500, cash or
surety.

Delyn Johnson, 20, of Jonesboro, two counts of second-degree forgery, theft of
$1,000 or less; bond set at $1,500, cash or surety.

Monique Norris, 40, of Jonesboro, possession of drug paraphernalia, possession
of benzodiazepine less than 28 grams, third-degree domestic battering; bond
set at $7,500, cash or surety.

Bryan Redden, 37, of Brookland, first-degree terroristic threatening; bond set
at $5,500, cash or surety.

Ricky Shirley, 39, of Monette, possession of a meth or cocaine more than 2
grams but less than 200 grams with the purpose to deliver, possession of a
meth or cocaine more than 2 grams but less than 200 grams, possession of drug
paraphernalia, possession of marijuana less than 4 ounces; bond set at
$150,000, cash or surety.

Jamie Thomas, 64, of Bono, possession of meth less than 2 grams, possession of
drug paraphernalia; bond set at $1,500, cash or surety.

Todd Willbanks, 47, of Jonesboro, possession of meth or cocaine greater 2
grams but less than 10 grams with the purpose to deliver, possession of drug
paraphernalia, breaking or entering, theft of items valued at $1,000 or less;
bond set at $35,000, cash or surety.

Restoration House resident escapes, found in Conway

JONESBORO \- A woman in state custody reportedly escaped Thursday night from
the Restoration House, 534 W. Washington Ave.

Misty Arnold, 46, of Jonesboro, left the group home at 7:17 p.m., according to
the JPD incident report. Court documents show that Arnold was sentenced to
seven years in prison in October 2019 for possession of drugs and drug
paraphernalia.

A probation officer found Arnold's ankle monitor in a gravel parking lot near
the intersection of Huntington Avenue and Flint Street.

"The workers  stated that Suspect No. 1 was more than likely headed to Little
Rock," the report read.

Detective Vic Brooks was informed Friday morning that Arnold was taken into
custody in Conway and had been transported to the McPherson Unit in Newport.

"I was told that the D.O.C. (Arkansas Department of Corrections) was pursuing
charges themselves for the felony escape," Brooks wrote.

Other reports:

Kum & Go, 2607 Red Wolf Blvd., first-degree forgery.

1800 block of Greensboro Road, breaking or entering a black 2019 Kia Sorento,
theft of items valued at $1,000 or less.

2000 block of Cedar Heights Drive, aggravated assault, first-degree
terroristic threatening.

4700 block of Peter Trail, second-degree forgery.

Arkansas Progressive Medicine, 1000 E. Matthews Ave. Suite E, theft of
credit/debit cards, theft of items valued at $1,000 or less.

3900 block of Lindberg Drive, breaking or entering a black 2019 Toyota
4-Runner, theft of firearm valued at $2,500 or less.

100 block of East Allen Avenue, first-degree terroristic threatening, breaking
or entering a building, third-degree battery, first-degree criminal mischief
causing property damage valued at $1,000 or less.

2300 block of Willow Road, breaking or entering a 2010 Chevrolet Camero, theft
of items valued at more than $5,000 but less than $25,000 from a vehicle.

title: Police/Courts for May 24, 2020
html:
Police: Man attacks family member

JONESBORO - A man suspected of assaulting a female family member Wednesday was being held in jail on a $150,000 bond.

The victim reported Wednesday that Nathaniel Rhodes, 37, of Jonesboro, broke into her house and attacked her while she was sleeping in the 1000 block of Ferrell Street, reports state. According to the Jonesboro Police Department incident report, Rhodes picked the lock on the back door to enter the home.

"She reported that Rhodes repeatedly punched and choked her during the assault. … Rhodes took his hand and covered her mouth and nose," the probable cause affidavit read. "When Rhodes was attacking the victim, he made threats that he was going to kill her."

District Court Judge Tommy Fowler found probable cause Friday to charge Rhodes with residential burglary, aggravated assault on a family or household member and first-degree terroristic threatening.

As a pre-trial condition, Fowler said Rhodes is required to wear an ankle monitor if he is released from jail. A no-contact order between him and the victim was also imposed.

-----

The judge also found probable cause for charges and set bond for the following:

Michael Bridgeman, 30, of Jonesboro, possession of meth less than 2 grams, possession of drug paraphernalia; bond set at $3,500, cash or surety.

Daniel Cohn, 29, of Jonesboro, possession of drug paraphernalia; bond set at $1,500, cash or surety.

Danna Holt, 36, of Leachville, possession of meth less than 2 grams, possession of marijuana less than 4 ounces; bond set at $1,500, cash or surety.

Delyn Johnson, 20, of Jonesboro, two counts of second-degree forgery, theft of $1,000 or less; bond set at $1,500, cash or surety.

Monique Norris, 40, of Jonesboro, possession of drug paraphernalia, possession of benzodiazepine less than 28 grams, third-degree domestic battering; bond set at $7,500, cash or surety.

Bryan Redden, 37, of Brookland, first-degree terroristic threatening; bond set at $5,500, cash or surety.

Ricky Shirley, 39, of Monette, possession of a meth or cocaine more than 2 grams but less than 200 grams with the purpose to deliver, possession of a meth or cocaine more than 2 grams but less than 200 grams, possession of drug paraphernalia, possession of marijuana less than 4 ounces; bond set at $150,000, cash or surety.

Jamie Thomas, 64, of Bono, possession of meth less than 2 grams, possession of drug paraphernalia; bond set at $1,500, cash or surety.

Todd Willbanks, 47, of Jonesboro, possession of meth or cocaine greater 2 grams but less than 10 grams with the purpose to deliver, possession of drug paraphernalia, breaking or entering, theft of items valued at $1,000 or less; bond set at $35,000, cash or surety.

Restoration House resident escapes, found in Conway

JONESBORO - A woman in state custody reportedly escaped Thursday night from the Restoration House, 534 W. Washington Ave.

Misty Arnold, 46, of Jonesboro, left the group home at 7:17 p.m., according to the JPD incident report. Court documents show that Arnold was sentenced to seven years in prison in October 2019 for possession of drugs and drug paraphernalia.

A probation officer found Arnold's ankle monitor in a gravel parking lot near the intersection of Huntington Avenue and Flint Street.

"The workers … stated that Suspect No. 1 was more than likely headed to Little Rock," the report read.

Detective Vic Brooks was informed Friday morning that Arnold was taken into custody in Conway and had been transported to the McPherson Unit in Newport.

"I was told that the D.O.C. (Arkansas Department of Corrections) was pursuing charges themselves for the felony escape," Brooks wrote.

Other reports:

Kum & Go, 2607 Red Wolf Blvd., first-degree forgery.

1800 block of Greensboro Road, breaking or entering a black 2019 Kia Sorento, theft of items valued at $1,000 or less.

2000 block of Cedar Heights Drive, aggravated assault, first-degree terroristic threatening.

4700 block of Peter Trail, second-degree forgery.

Arkansas Progressive Medicine, 1000 E. Matthews Ave. Suite E, theft of credit/debit cards, theft of items valued at $1,000 or less.

3900 block of Lindberg Drive, breaking or entering a black 2019 Toyota 4-Runner, theft of firearm valued at $2,500 or less.

100 block of East Allen Avenue, first-degree terroristic threatening, breaking or entering a building, third-degree battery, first-degree criminal mischief causing property damage valued at $1,000 or less.

2300 block of Willow Road, breaking or entering a 2010 Chevrolet Camero, theft of items valued at more than $5,000 but less than $25,000 from a vehicle.
